titleproper.value: Guide to the Robert Gruenwald Papers <num>TAM 687</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-07-12T14:52:09</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

extent.value: in 2 record cartons and 1 12-inch vinly disc

abstract.value: The Robert Gruenwald Papers (dates 1953-1986) consist of flyers, bulletins, periodicals, and pamphlets related to Gruenwald's involvement in labor organizing and leftist politics. Robert Gruenwald was a labor organizer and activist in leftist student politics in New York City in the 1970s and 1980s. The bulk of the collection relates to his membership in the American Postal Workers Union and the New York Metro Area Postal Workers' Union, and consists of flyers, bulletins, newspaper clippings, and mailings about union elections. The collection also contains copies periodicals inlcuding issues of <emph render="italic">The American Postal Worker</emph> (1974-1986), <emph render="italic">Union Mail</emph> (1978-1985), <emph render="italic">The Worker for the New York-New Jersey Area</emph> (1973-1978), <emph render="italic">Revolution</emph> (Revolutionary Union, 1973), and <emph render="italic">The Red Papers</emph> (1969-1972). Pamphlets relate to a variety of topics on workers and civil rights, student activism, China, the Vietnam War, and organizations on the political left.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Robert Gruenwald Papers; TAM 687; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library & Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Robert Gruenwald in 2016. The accession number associated with this gift is 2016.029.

Robert Gruenwald was a labor organizer and activist in leftist student politics in New York City in the 1970s and 1980s. He was a student at Columbia University in the early 1970s, organizing around anti-war and local campus issues. Later he became active in the labor movement working to promote union democracy and trade unionism. He served as a shop steward in the New York Metro Area Postal Workers Union for 5 years.
Also included in the collection is a 1976 vinyl record of labor songs titled, <emph render="italic">Break the Chains</emph>, by Prarie Fire.
